samples.source:
floyd mayweather v manny pacquiao will be the biggest fight of all time financially and the most significant this century . 
evaluating the greatest ever fights is a complex variable of several factors including not only the quality and excitement of the action but the political , social and cultural undertones , the scale of expectation and outside influences . 
where money man v pacman comes to rank among the most important fights in ring history will depend upon what happens that coming night in the mgm grand garden arena . 
in this , the sixth in a series of 12 fights that shaped boxing history , i recall when a hard man could take no more ...
sugar ray leonard v roberto duran
the first two of the three fights between the sugar man and hands of stone raised the curtain on what is considered the golden age of boxing in the classic middling weights of boxing , with ray leonard , roberto duran , thomas hearns and marvin hagler engaging each other in some of the ring 's epic battles . 
by way of a preview , leonard had defeated the previous -- and equally great -- felix trinidad to win the world welterweight title . 
sugar ray leonard celebrates after roberto duran quit in their fight in louisiana in november 1980
leonard decided to use his exceptional speed and movement to beat the panamanian in the second fight
october 30 , 1974 , kinshasa , zaire
march 8 , 1971 , madison square garden , new york
july 4 , 1910 , reno , nevada
june 22 , 1938 , yankee stadium , new york
october 1 , 1975 , quezon city , philippines
in his first defence , sugar ray had been contentiously outpointed by duran in montreal 's olympic stadium . 
so confused was the scoring that the result was first announced as a majority decision . 
that was changed to unanimous in duran 's favour after one judge was found to have totalled his score incorrectly and his card was altered from a draw to 148-147 . 
there was more uproar when that judge was revealed to have marked just three rounds in favour of duran and only two for leonard -- with 10 even . 
that was described as ` a monument to indecision ' . 
come the inevitable rematch eight months later , in the louisana superdome in new orleans on november 25 , 1980 , controversy was to be replaced by disbelief . 
leonard had gambled in the first fight by taking the macho decision to take on the panamanian hard man in a mano-a-mano slug-out . 
second time around he wisely chose to use his exceptional ability , especially his speed and movement . 
duran became frustrated as leonard danced around him before unleashing his punches
after being caught flush in the face in the eighth round , duran turned his back and said ` no mas '
` the whole fight i was moving . 
then voom , i 'd snap his head back with a jab . 
voom , i 'd snap it back again . 
he 'd try to get me on the ropes . 
i 'd pivot , spin off and pow , come under with a punch . ' 
so it went for more than seven rounds , with duran becoming increasingly frustrated . 
in the eighth leonard cranked up the psychological pressure by waving his right arm in circles and then planting a left flush in duran 's face . 
there had been a moment earlier when leonard appeared to pat him playfully on the backside . 
just before the bell duran turned his back and walked to his corner , waving his arms to indicate he was finished and famously telling the referee : ` no mas . ' 
leonard celebrates after his opponent quit , and said it was more of an achievement than knocking duran out
the result stunned the watching world , and it took three years for duran to rebuild his reputation
the watching world was stunned . 
here was one of the most heroic warriors in boxing history quitting in the most humiliating manner possible . 
sensing the reaction duran claimed he had stomach cramps caused by eating too heavily after the morning weigh-in . 
but his manager carlos eleta said : ` he always eats like that before a fight . 
he quit because he was embarrassed . ' 
duran had been a national icon in panama and there was anger on the streets at his action . 
television commercials featuring him were taken off . 
it took three years for duran to restore his high place in his country 's esteem . 
he did so on june 16 , 1983 , his 32nd birthday , by knocking out davey moore in las vegas to win the world light-middleweight title . 
rejoicing returned to the streets . 
leonard would win their third fight in 1989 by a points landslide , thereby retaining the world super-middleweight title . 
but sugar ray took most pride from the trilogy from forcing duran to say no mas . 
he said : ` to me , making roberto duran to quit was better than knocking him out . '
samples.summary:
he passage describes the sixth significant fight in boxing history, Floyd Mayweather vs Manny Pacquiao, which is anticipated to be the most financially successful and significant fight of the century. The summary focuses on the Sugar Ray Leonard vs Roberto Duran trilogy, considered the golden age of boxing in the classic middleweights. 

In their first fight, Duran outpointed Leonard in Montreal, leading to a controversial result. In the second fight, Leonard used his speed and movement to frustrate Duran, who eventually quit in the eighth round, saying "no mas." This event was met with shock and disbelief, as Duran was known for his heroic and tough fighting style. It took Duran three years to rebuild his reputation, which he did by knocking out Davey Moore in 1983 to win the world light-middleweight title. 

In their third fight, Leonard retained the world super-middleweight title by a points landslide. Leonard took most pride from the trilogy for forcing Duran to say "no mas." The passage suggests that the outcome of the Mayweather vs Pacquiao fight will determine its ranking among the most

samples.summary:
he passage discusses the anticipated Floyd Mayweather vs Manny Pacquiao fight, which is considered potentially the biggest fight of all time financially and the most significant in the century. The author emphasizes that determining the greatest fights involves various factors, including political, social, and cultural aspects. The outcome of Mayweather vs. Pacquiao will depend on their upcoming match at the MGM Grand Garden Arena. 

The passage also highlights the historical significance of the Sugar Ray Leonard vs. Roberto Duran fights, which took place in the 1970s and 1980s. The first fight in 1971 ended controversially, with Duran initially declared the winner. The rematch in 1980 saw Duran quit in the eighth round, a decision that shocked the world and led to a three-year period of rebuilding his reputation. Duran eventually regained his status by winning the world light-middleweight title in 1983. 

Sugar Ray Leonard expressed pride in forcing Roberto Duran to quit rather than knocking him out, stating that it was a better outcome for him

samples.summary:
Here's a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information:

The passage discusses the significance of the Sugar Ray Leonard vs. Roberto Duran fights in boxing history. It focuses on their second bout on November 25, 1980, in New Orleans. In their first fight, Duran won a controversial decision. For the rematch, Leonard changed his strategy, using his speed and movement to frustrate Duran. In the eighth round, Leonard's tactics and psychological pressure led Duran to quit, famously saying "No mas" (No more). This shocking outcome stunned the boxing world and temporarily damaged Duran's reputation in Panama. Leonard considered forcing Duran to quit a greater achievement than knocking him out. The passage also mentions their third fight in 1989, which Leonard won decisively. These fights were part of a series that shaped boxing history and marked the beginning of a golden age in the middleweight divisions.

samples.summary: The upcoming fight between Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao is anticipated to be the most significant and financially lucrative boxing match of the century. The passage then shifts focus to a historic fight between Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran, part of a series highlighting significant boxing matches. Leonard's strategy shift in the rematch, utilizing his speed and movement, led to Duran's unexpected surrender, causing a global shock and impacting Duran's reputation for years.

samples.source:
floyd mayweather v manny pacquiao will be the biggest fight of all time financially and the most significant this century . 
evaluating the greatest ever fights is a complex variable of several factors including not only the quality and excitement of the action but the political , social and cultural undertones , the scale of expectation and outside influences . 
where money man v pacman comes to rank among the most important fights in ring history will depend upon what happens that coming night in the mgm grand garden arena . 
in this , the sixth in a series of 12 fights that shaped boxing history , i recall when a hard man could take no more ...
sugar ray leonard v roberto duran
the first two of the three fights between the sugar man and hands of stone raised the curtain on what is considered the golden age of boxing in the classic middling weights of boxing , with ray leonard , roberto duran , thomas hearns and marvin hagler engaging each other in some of the ring 's epic battles . 
by way of a preview , leonard had defeated the previous -- and equally great -- felix trinidad to win the world welterweight title . 
sugar ray leonard celebrates after roberto duran quit in their fight in louisiana in november 1980
leonard decided to use his exceptional speed and movement to beat the panamanian in the second fight
october 30 , 1974 , kinshasa , zaire
march 8 , 1971 , madison square garden , new york
july 4 , 1910 , reno , nevada
june 22 , 1938 , yankee stadium , new york
october 1 , 1975 , quezon city , philippines
in his first defence , sugar ray had been contentiously outpointed by duran in montreal 's olympic stadium . 
so confused was the scoring that the result was first announced as a majority decision . 
that was changed to unanimous in duran 's favour after one judge was found to have totalled his score incorrectly and his card was altered from a draw to 148-147 . 
there was more uproar when that judge was revealed to have marked just three rounds in favour of duran and only two for leonard -- with 10 even . 
that was described as ` a monument to indecision ' . 
come the inevitable rematch eight months later , in the louisana superdome in new orleans on november 25 , 1980 , controversy was to be replaced by disbelief . 
leonard had gambled in the first fight by taking the macho decision to take on the panamanian hard man in a mano-a-mano slug-out . 
second time around he wisely chose to use his exceptional ability , especially his speed and movement . 
duran became frustrated as leonard danced around him before unleashing his punches
after being caught flush in the face in the eighth round , duran turned his back and said ` no mas '
` the whole fight i was moving . 
then voom , i 'd snap his head back with a jab . 
voom , i 'd snap it back again . 
he 'd try to get me on the ropes . 
i 'd pivot , spin off and pow , come under with a punch . ' 
so it went for more than seven rounds , with duran becoming increasingly frustrated . 
in the eighth leonard cranked up the psychological pressure by waving his right arm in circles and then planting a left flush in duran 's face . 
there had been a moment earlier when leonard appeared to pat him playfully on the backside . 
just before the bell duran turned his back and walked to his corner , waving his arms to indicate he was finished and famously telling the referee : ` no mas . ' 
leonard celebrates after his opponent quit , and said it was more of an achievement than knocking duran out
the result stunned the watching world , and it took three years for duran to rebuild his reputation
the watching world was stunned . 
here was one of the most heroic warriors in boxing history quitting in the most humiliating manner possible . 
sensing the reaction duran claimed he had stomach cramps caused by eating too heavily after the morning weigh-in . 
but his manager carlos eleta said : ` he always eats like that before a fight . 
he quit because he was embarrassed . ' 
duran had been a national icon in panama and there was anger on the streets at his action . 
television commercials featuring him were taken off . 
it took three years for duran to restore his high place in his country 's esteem . 
he did so on june 16 , 1983 , his 32nd birthday , by knocking out davey moore in las vegas to win the world light-middleweight title . 
rejoicing returned to the streets . 
leonard would win their third fight in 1989 by a points landslide , thereby retaining the world super-middleweight title . 
but sugar ray took most pride from the trilogy from forcing duran to say no mas . 
he said : ` to me , making roberto duran to quit was better than knocking him out . '
samples.summary: The passage discusses the significance of boxing matches, focusing on the Floyd Mayweather vs. Manny Pacquiao fight as the most financially lucrative and impactful of the century. It also delves into the Sugar Ray Leonard vs. Roberto Duran trilogy, highlighting the first two fights that marked the golden age of boxing. The third fight, held in New Orleans, ended with Duran's controversial "No Mas" gesture, which stunned the world and took years for Duran to recover from both professionally and personally.

The two fighters had a trilogy of fights, with Duran initially outpointing Leonard in their first fight, but then quitting in the second fight in 1980, famously saying "no mas." Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The upcoming fight between Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao is expected to be the biggest and most significant fight of the century. However, the passage primarily focuses on the epic battle between Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran, which is considered one of the greatest fights in ring history. The two fighters had a trilogy of fights, with the first fight in 1980 being won by Duran in a contentious decision. In the rematch, Leonard used his exceptional speed and movement to outmaneuver Duran, who became frustrated and quit in the eighth round, famously saying "no mas." The result was a shock to the world, and it took Duran three years to rebuild his reputation. Leonard went on to win the third fight in 1989, and he considers forcing Duran to quit as one of his greatest achievements.

samples.summary: The fight between Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran is considered one of the most important fights in boxing history. The first two fights of their trilogy were considered to be part of the golden age of boxing. Leonard won the first fight by outpointing Duran, but the scoring was controversial. In the rematch, Leonard used his speed and movement to frustrate Duran, who eventually quit in the eighth round, saying "no mas." This was a humiliating defeat for Duran, who was a national icon in Panama. It took him three years to rebuild his reputation and regain his country's esteem. Leonard would go on to win their third fight in 1989, but he considered forcing Duran to quit to be a greater achievement than knocking him out.

floyd mayweather v manny pacquiao will be the biggest fight of all time financially and the most significant this century . 
evaluating the greatest ever fights is a complex variable of several factors including not only the quality and excitement of the action but the political , social and cultural undertones , the scale of expectation and outside influences . 
where money man v pacman comes to rank among the most important fights in ring history will depend upon what happens that coming night in the mgm grand garden arena . 
in this , the sixth in a series of 12 fights that shaped boxing history , i recall when a hard man could take no more ...
sugar ray leonard v roberto duran
the first two of the three fights between the sugar man and hands of stone raised the curtain on what is considered the golden age of boxing in the classic middling weights of boxing , with ray leonard , roberto duran , thomas hearns and marvin hagler engaging each other in some of the ring 's epic battles . 
by way of a preview , leonard had defeated the previous -- and equally great -- felix trinidad to win the world welterweight title . 
sugar ray leonard celebrates after roberto duran quit in their fight in louisiana in november 1980
leonard decided to use his exceptional speed and movement to beat the panamanian in the second fight

march 8 , 1971 , madison square garden , new york
july 4 , 1910 , reno , nevada
june 22 , 1938 , yankee stadium , new york
october 1 , 1975 , quezon city , philippines
in his first defence , sugar ray had been contentiously outpointed by duran in montreal 's olympic stadium . 
so confused was the scoring that the result was first announced as a majority decision . 
that was changed to unanimous in duran 's favour after one judge was found to have totalled his score incorrectly and his card was altered from a draw to 148-147 . 
there was more uproar when that judge was revealed to have marked just three rounds in favour of duran and only two for leonard -- with 10 even . 
that was described as ` a monument to indecision ' . 
come the inevitable rematch eight months later , in the louisana superdome in new orleans on november 25 , 1980 , controversy was to be replaced by disbelief . 
leonard had gambled in the first fight by taking the macho decision to take on the panamanian hard man in a mano-a-mano slug-out . 
second time around he wisely chose to use his exceptional ability , especially his speed and movement . 
duran became frustrated as leonard danced around him before unleashing his punches
after being caught flush in the face in the eighth round , duran turned his back and said ` no mas '
` the whole fight i was moving . 
then voom , i 'd snap his head back with a jab . 
voom , i 'd snap it back again . 
he 'd try to get me on the ropes . 
i 'd pivot , spin off and pow , come under with a punch . ' 
so it went for more than seven rounds , with duran becoming increasingly frustrated . 
in the eighth leonard cranked up the psychological pressure by waving his right arm in circles and then planting a left flush in duran 's face . 
there had been a moment earlier when leonard appeared to pat him playfully on the backside . 
just before the bell duran turned his back and walked to his corner , waving his arms to indicate he was finished and famously telling the referee : ` no mas . ' 
leonard celebrates after his opponent quit , and said it was more of an achievement than knocking duran out
the result stunned the watching world , and it took three years for duran to rebuild his reputation

here was one of the most heroic warriors in boxing history quitting in the most humiliating manner possible .

rejoicing returned to the streets . 
leonard would win their third fight in 1989 by a points landslide , thereby retaining the world super-middleweight title . 
but sugar ray took most pride from the trilogy from forcing duran to say no mas . 
he said : ` to me , making roberto duran to quit was better than knocking him out . '

samples.source:
rory mcilroy believes it is ` unthinkable ' that he will not win the masters at some point to complete the career grand slam . 
and the world number one has revealed how his final-round collapse at augusta national in 2011 was the most important day of his career . 
mcilroy is looking to claim his first green jacket and become just the sixth player to win all four major titles after gene sarazen , ben hogan , gary player , jack nicklaus and tiger woods . 
rory mcilroy tees off at the arnold palmer invitational golf tournament in orlando on march 19
` for me now it 's a career-long goal to win there to achieve something that only a handful of players have ever achieved , ' the 25-year-old said in an interview with bbc northern ireland . 
` there 's something special i can achieve going into augusta this year . 
you are a complete player if you can win every major because they are on different golf courses , different tests , different conditions . 
not many guys have done it in history so to put my name there would be awesome . 
it would just be incredible . 
` you feel the sense of what can be achieved but i ca n't think about that too much . 
i just have to think about trying to go out there and playing as best as i can and if i can do that hopefully my scores add up to a shot lower than anyone else 's . ' 
mcilroy has just one top-10 finish to his name in six masters appearances , finishing joint eighth last year despite the embarrassment of being outscored by his marker in the third round . 
mcilroy is hoping to complete his grand slam of majors with a victory at augusta later this month
but the 25-year-old can not picture going through his career without slipping on at least one coveted green jacket . 
` during my career , yes it 's unthinkable , ' he added . 
` if i do n't win it this year ... either it 's not the right time or it is n't your time . 
if i was to look back as a 60-year-old on my career and not have won a green jacket i 'd obviously be very , very disappointed . 
` and not just one . 
i feel like it 's a course i can do very well at and a golf course i can hopefully win multiple times on . 
obviously getting that first one is extra important and from there we can go on and maybe think about getting some others . ' 
mcilroy held a four-shot lead going into the final round four years ago , only to collapse to a closing 80 and finish 10 shots behind the winner charl schwartzel . 
but he bounced back to win his first major title by eight shots in the us open two months later , before adding wins in the 2012 us pga and both the open and us pga last year . 
mcilroy is hoping to emulate the likes of jack nicklaus ( above ) by winning all four major titles
` i think it was the most important day of my career , ' he added . 
` if i had n't had the whole unravelling and say i just made a couple of bogeys coming down the stretch and lost by one , i might not have learnt as much . 
` but for it all to come apart how it did i learnt an awful lot . 
i learnt so much about myself and my game and what i needed to do differently the next time i was in that position . 
` luckily it did n't take me long to get into a position like that again where i was leading a major and we know how that one played out . 
i was able to get over the line pretty comfortably . ' 
mcilroy 's extraordinary success last year came despite the distractions of calling off his wedding to caroline wozniacki and a legal dispute with his former management company which cost him millions of pounds when it was finally settled in february . 
mcilroy 's extraordinary success last year came he called off his wedding to caroline wozniacki
and he hopes he can again use the golf course as his ` sanctuary ' from the pressure and hype surrounding augusta . 
` the golf course was my sanctuary , it was where i could get away from everything and just not have to think about it for the four or five hours that i am out there and it helped . 
it really did , ' he added . 
` i was looking forward to getting to the course and playing and practising and i think it will be the same at augusta because there will be so much hype and build up and talk about what could happen . 
` i know i wo n't be able to wait until thursday morning or afternoon and just get on the golf course and play golf . 
there is only so much you can talk about it and then you have to go out and try and play . '
samples.summary: ory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, aims to win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, joining an elite group of six players who have achieved this feat. He considers winning the Masters as a career-long goal and believes it is "unthinkable" not to win it at some point. McIlroy has had one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, but he is hoping to win his first green jacket this year. He has previously experienced a collapse in the final round of the Masters in 2011, which he considers the most important day of his career as it taught him valuable lessons about himself and his game. McIlroy is set to tee off at the Arnold Palmer Invitational Golf Tournament on March 19. Despite the distractions of calling off his wedding and a legal dispute, McIlroy had an extraordinary successful year in 2014, winning multiple majors. He hopes to use the golf course as his "sanctuary" from the pressure and hype surrounding the Masters.

Here's a concise summary of the core information in the passage:

Rory McIlroy, the world's top-ranked golfer, is aiming to win the Masters tournament to complete a career grand slam. He believes it's "unthinkable" that he won't win it at some point in his career. McIlroy sees his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. He would join an elite group of only five other golfers who have won all four major titles if he succeeds. Despite the pressure and hype surrounding the tournament, McIlroy views the golf course as his "sanctuary" where he can focus solely on his game. He's eager to start playing and hopes to win multiple green jackets in his career.

samples.source:
rory mcilroy believes it is ` unthinkable ' that he will not win the masters at some point to complete the career grand slam . 
and the world number one has revealed how his final-round collapse at augusta national in 2011 was the most important day of his career . 
mcilroy is looking to claim his first green jacket and become just the sixth player to win all four major titles after gene sarazen , ben hogan , gary player , jack nicklaus and tiger woods . 
rory mcilroy tees off at the arnold palmer invitational golf tournament in orlando on march 19
` for me now it 's a career-long goal to win there to achieve something that only a handful of players have ever achieved , ' the 25-year-old said in an interview with bbc northern ireland . 
` there 's something special i can achieve going into augusta this year . 
you are a complete player if you can win every major because they are on different golf courses , different tests , different conditions . 
not many guys have done it in history so to put my name there would be awesome . 
it would just be incredible . 
` you feel the sense of what can be achieved but i ca n't think about that too much . 
i just have to think about trying to go out there and playing as best as i can and if i can do that hopefully my scores add up to a shot lower than anyone else 's . ' 
mcilroy has just one top-10 finish to his name in six masters appearances , finishing joint eighth last year despite the embarrassment of being outscored by his marker in the third round . 
mcilroy is hoping to complete his grand slam of majors with a victory at augusta later this month
but the 25-year-old can not picture going through his career without slipping on at least one coveted green jacket . 
` during my career , yes it 's unthinkable , ' he added . 
` if i do n't win it this year ... either it 's not the right time or it is n't your time . 
if i was to look back as a 60-year-old on my career and not have won a green jacket i 'd obviously be very , very disappointed . 
` and not just one . 
i feel like it 's a course i can do very well at and a golf course i can hopefully win multiple times on . 
obviously getting that first one is extra important and from there we can go on and maybe think about getting some others . ' 
mcilroy held a four-shot lead going into the final round four years ago , only to collapse to a closing 80 and finish 10 shots behind the winner charl schwartzel . 
but he bounced back to win his first major title by eight shots in the us open two months later , before adding wins in the 2012 us pga and both the open and us pga last year . 
mcilroy is hoping to emulate the likes of jack nicklaus ( above ) by winning all four major titles
` i think it was the most important day of my career , ' he added . 
` if i had n't had the whole unravelling and say i just made a couple of bogeys coming down the stretch and lost by one , i might not have learnt as much . 
` but for it all to come apart how it did i learnt an awful lot . 
i learnt so much about myself and my game and what i needed to do differently the next time i was in that position . 
` luckily it did n't take me long to get into a position like that again where i was leading a major and we know how that one played out . 
i was able to get over the line pretty comfortably . ' 
mcilroy 's extraordinary success last year came despite the distractions of calling off his wedding to caroline wozniacki and a legal dispute with his former management company which cost him millions of pounds when it was finally settled in february . 
mcilroy 's extraordinary success last year came he called off his wedding to caroline wozniacki
and he hopes he can again use the golf course as his ` sanctuary ' from the pressure and hype surrounding augusta . 
` the golf course was my sanctuary , it was where i could get away from everything and just not have to think about it for the four or five hours that i am out there and it helped . 
it really did , ' he added . 
` i was looking forward to getting to the course and playing and practising and i think it will be the same at augusta because there will be so much hype and build up and talk about what could happen . 
` i know i wo n't be able to wait until thursday morning or afternoon and just get on the golf course and play golf . 
there is only so much you can talk about it and then you have to go out and try and play . '
samples.summary: Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He considers his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career. McIlroy is aiming to become the sixth player to win all four major titles. He has just one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances but is determined to win a green jacket. McIlroy sees Augusta as a course he can do well on and hopes to win multiple times. He learned a lot from his collapse in 2011 and bounced back to win his first major title two months later. McIlroy's success last year came despite personal distractions. He sees the golf course as his sanctuary and hopes to use it to escape the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta.

samples.summary: Rory McIlroy is determined to win the Masters to complete his career grand slam, a feat achieved by only five other players. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta National as the most pivotal day of his career, teaching him valuable lessons. Despite only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy is confident he will eventually win the green jacket, viewing it as a career-long goal. He aims to use the golf course as a sanctuary from external pressures, similar to how he managed distractions during his successful 2014 season.

label: Questionable
annotations.note:
This one is tough but I think earning his Grand Slam and a green jacket are being conflated here.

Winning a grand slam seems to be the "career-long goal" and winning a green jacket (or multiple) is important, but a seemingly secondary goal.

This could be an unwanted hallucination but I'm not entirely certain.

samples.source:
pablo mandado and ilze zebolde have no plans , no agenda , no cause to fight for and they are certainly in no hurry -- the couple simply has a dream to ` discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time . ' 
and , after quitting their restaurant jobs in manchester , the intrepid cyclists are doing it as cheaply as they possibly can . 
spanish pablo , 27 , and latvian ilze , 31 , who met in riga in 2011 , are off to a flying start as they approach their first year of their open-ended odyssey on the road . 
in 356 days so far they 've covered almost 7,000 miles ( 11,131.92 km by their measurements ) and been through 16 countries . 
ilze zebolde , 31 , takes in her surrounds as she and pablo mandado take a break in their cycle journey around the world
pablo , 27 , and ilze , 31 , stop for a picture in bosnia , one of the 16 countries they 've been through since leaving london last year
latvian ilze sets up camp , the most common means of accommodation for her and pablo , on the stunning lake bled in slovenia
ilze points at the winding road that she and pablo had climb in spain 's sierra nevada with their 130 kg of gear ( including bicycles )
with no plans or agenda , ilze and pablo are happy to stop and take in stunning views , such as this from a roadside in the french alps
in that time they have been astonishingly living on less than three euros each a day , or by their meticulous calculations 10 euro cents per kilometre . 
they keep costs down by relying on free accommodation , along with not needing a budget for transport -- their legs have that covered . 
usually they pitch a tent under the stars and camp ( 161 nights of the 256 ) but also use hosting websites such as couchsurfing ( 66 nights ) and warmshowers ( 44 nights ) . 
sometimes , they get a good night 's sleep courtesy of the kindness of strangers . 
showers are ` sometimes daily , sometimes weekly , ' admits pablo . 
this leaves food as their only major expense , and that takes up just 2.74 euros each per day of their 2.99 total outlay . 
ilze often stars in their images with pablo the designated photographer , but she does n't seem to mind after another hill climb
pablo gives up his camera for a moment , though , as latvian ilze captures her spanish boyfriend taking a rest on the road
while they often pitch their tent in stunning settings , this pedestrian tunnel during their journey through turkey is n't one of them
rolling green hills and a shimmering lake greeted the duo in the alps as their open-ended odyssey continued
when asked on their blog , thecrazytravel , how they can possibly live like this , pablo answered simply . 
` pasta , bread , rice , eggs , milk , seasonal fruits and vegetables . 
often we get invited for a meal , or for some free veggies or fruits , ' he said . 
` we pick up wild fruits occasionally as well , and dumpster diving was an option in western countries where half of the food production end up in the bin . ' 
pablo and ilze started in london before heading south-east and working their way through france , first down the west coast and then the south after a loop through spain and portugal . 
pedal power then took them through the north of italy , slovenia , croatia , bosnia and herzegovina , montenegro , albania , macedonia , greece and into turkey . 
ilze walks with her bike while pablo trails behind to capture a snowy landscape in turkey , which they traversed the entire north of
pablo and ilze 's tent in a field in bosnia - this is their usual means of accommodation although they often use hosting websites
pabo and ilze take a break in an italian mountain town as they work their way from france towards eastern europe
pablo rides along the waterside in thessaloniki , greece , one of more than 222 stops they 've made in their journey so far
all landscapes and settings are greeting pablo and ilze , including moody forests in france as they rode along both coasts
ilze rides into the clouds as pedal power takes her and pablo through eastern europe and towards asia , their next continent
the view from pablo and ilze 's tent as they awake to another day in the saddle as they live out their dream
pablo shows off the huge amount of gear he and ilze need to carry as they work their way around the world
` cycling over the bridge at the border between greece and turkey was symbolic , ' pablo says . 
` riding away from europe , finally crossing into a different continent . 
finally going further away and into the unknown . ' 
they traversed the entire northern coast of turkey , before riding through georgia and their latest destination , armenia , and they plan to ` continue into asia , across the pacific with the idea to cycle all the length of the american continent . ' 
` we are going to be on the road for the following years , ' they say .
samples.summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple, have embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They started their odyssey in London and have covered approximately 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. They live frugally, spending less than three euros each per day, and rely on free accommodation, such as camping, couchsurfing, and warmshowers, to keep costs down. Their primary expense is food, which takes up about 2.74 euros each per day. They document their journey on their blog, thecrazytravel, and share tips on how they manage to live so inexpensively, such as relying on wild fruits, dumpster diving, and accepting invitations for meals. They plan to continue their journey through Asia, across the Pacific, and eventually cycle the length of the American continent.

label: Questionable
annotations.note:
Camping is the accommodation itself. Couchsurfing and warmshowers are websites used to book free accommodations where Couchsurfing is both the accommodation and the tool used to find/book it.

This may be a form of hallucination since it seems to conflate them all as accommodations (maybe reader dependent)

samples.summary:
Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Riga, Latvia and Spain respectively, embarked on a year-long cycling journey around the world in 2011. They quit their jobs in Manchester, UK, and started their adventure with no plans, agenda, or cause to fight for. They aim to discover different parts of the planet, one pedal at a time. 

The couple, aged 27 and 31, have been traveling through 16 countries, covering almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) so far. They live on less than three euros each per day, or 10 euro cents per kilometer, by relying on free accommodation and not needing a budget for transport. They camp under the stars for 161 nights and use hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers for the remaining nights. 

Their diet mainly consists of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits, and vegetables, with occasional free meals, wild fruits, and even dumpster

samples.source:
pablo mandado and ilze zebolde have no plans , no agenda , no cause to fight for and they are certainly in no hurry -- the couple simply has a dream to ` discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time . ' 
and , after quitting their restaurant jobs in manchester , the intrepid cyclists are doing it as cheaply as they possibly can . 
spanish pablo , 27 , and latvian ilze , 31 , who met in riga in 2011 , are off to a flying start as they approach their first year of their open-ended odyssey on the road . 
in 356 days so far they 've covered almost 7,000 miles ( 11,131.92 km by their measurements ) and been through 16 countries . 
ilze zebolde , 31 , takes in her surrounds as she and pablo mandado take a break in their cycle journey around the world
pablo , 27 , and ilze , 31 , stop for a picture in bosnia , one of the 16 countries they 've been through since leaving london last year
latvian ilze sets up camp , the most common means of accommodation for her and pablo , on the stunning lake bled in slovenia
ilze points at the winding road that she and pablo had climb in spain 's sierra nevada with their 130 kg of gear ( including bicycles )
with no plans or agenda , ilze and pablo are happy to stop and take in stunning views , such as this from a roadside in the french alps
in that time they have been astonishingly living on less than three euros each a day , or by their meticulous calculations 10 euro cents per kilometre . 
they keep costs down by relying on free accommodation , along with not needing a budget for transport -- their legs have that covered . 
usually they pitch a tent under the stars and camp ( 161 nights of the 256 ) but also use hosting websites such as couchsurfing ( 66 nights ) and warmshowers ( 44 nights ) . 
sometimes , they get a good night 's sleep courtesy of the kindness of strangers . 
showers are ` sometimes daily , sometimes weekly , ' admits pablo . 
this leaves food as their only major expense , and that takes up just 2.74 euros each per day of their 2.99 total outlay . 
ilze often stars in their images with pablo the designated photographer , but she does n't seem to mind after another hill climb
pablo gives up his camera for a moment , though , as latvian ilze captures her spanish boyfriend taking a rest on the road
while they often pitch their tent in stunning settings , this pedestrian tunnel during their journey through turkey is n't one of them
rolling green hills and a shimmering lake greeted the duo in the alps as their open-ended odyssey continued
when asked on their blog , thecrazytravel , how they can possibly live like this , pablo answered simply . 
` pasta , bread , rice , eggs , milk , seasonal fruits and vegetables . 
often we get invited for a meal , or for some free veggies or fruits , ' he said . 
` we pick up wild fruits occasionally as well , and dumpster diving was an option in western countries where half of the food production end up in the bin . ' 
pablo and ilze started in london before heading south-east and working their way through france , first down the west coast and then the south after a loop through spain and portugal . 
pedal power then took them through the north of italy , slovenia , croatia , bosnia and herzegovina , montenegro , albania , macedonia , greece and into turkey . 
ilze walks with her bike while pablo trails behind to capture a snowy landscape in turkey , which they traversed the entire north of
pablo and ilze 's tent in a field in bosnia - this is their usual means of accommodation although they often use hosting websites
pabo and ilze take a break in an italian mountain town as they work their way from france towards eastern europe
pablo rides along the waterside in thessaloniki , greece , one of more than 222 stops they 've made in their journey so far
all landscapes and settings are greeting pablo and ilze , including moody forests in france as they rode along both coasts
ilze rides into the clouds as pedal power takes her and pablo through eastern europe and towards asia , their next continent
the view from pablo and ilze 's tent as they awake to another day in the saddle as they live out their dream
pablo shows off the huge amount of gear he and ilze need to carry as they work their way around the world
` cycling over the bridge at the border between greece and turkey was symbolic , ' pablo says . 
` riding away from europe , finally crossing into a different continent . 
finally going further away and into the unknown . ' 
they traversed the entire northern coast of turkey , before riding through georgia and their latest destination , armenia , and they plan to ` continue into asia , across the pacific with the idea to cycle all the length of the american continent . ' 
` we are going to be on the road for the following years , ' they say .
samples.summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who have quit their jobs and embarked on a cycling journey around the world. They have no specific plans or agenda, and their goal is to explore different parts of the planet at their own pace. They have been on the road for almost a year and have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live on a budget of less than three euros each per day, mainly spending on food. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping and hosting websites, to keep costs down. Their next destination is Asia, and they plan to continue cycling across the Pacific and through the entire length of the American continent. They anticipate being on the road for several more years.

samples.summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia respectively, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. They have no specific plans or agenda and aim to explore different parts of the planet one pedal at a time. In their first year, they have cycled almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day. They keep costs low by camping, using hosting websites, and occasionally relying on the kindness of strangers. Their journey started in London and has taken them through various European countries, and they plan to continue into Asia and eventually across the American continent.

samples.summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple, have embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They started their journey in London and have covered approximately 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. They live frugally, spending less than three euros each per day, and rely on free accommodation, such as camping, using hosting websites, and the kindness of strangers. Their main expense is food, which costs them around 2.74 euros each per day. They document their journey on their blog, TheCrazyTravel, and plan to continue cycling through Asia, across the Pacific, and eventually the American continent.

samples.summary:
Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Riga, Latvia and Spain respectively, embarked on a year-long cycling journey around the world in 2011. They quit their jobs in Manchester, UK, and started their adventure with no plans, agenda, or cause to fight for. They aim to discover different parts of the planet by cycling, and they do so as cheaply as possible. 

So far, they have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) and visited 16 countries, including France, Spain, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey. They live on less than three euros each per day, or 10 euro cents per kilometer, by relying on free accommodation and not needing a budget for transport. They camp under the stars for 161 nights and use hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers for the remaining nights. 

Their diet mainly consists of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are a couple cycling around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They quit their jobs in Manchester and have been on the road for 356 days, covering almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live on less than 3 euros each per day, mainly camping or using free accommodation services. Their journey started in London and has taken them through Western Europe, the Balkans, and into Turkey. They plan to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent. samples.summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia, respectively, embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no set plans or agenda. They quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and set off on an open-ended adventure. In the first year, they covered almost 7,000 miles, passing through 16 countries, including Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, and Turkey. They live frugally, spending less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation, and often camping. Food is their main expense, and they eat a simple diet of pasta, bread, rice, and seasonal produce, sometimes relying on the kindness of strangers for meals. They document their journey on their blog, thecrazytravel, and plan to continue cycling across Asia, the Pacific, and eventually the entire American continent.

samples.summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a 27-year-old Spanish man and 31-year-old Latvian woman, are on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. They quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and set off from London last year with no specific plans or agenda. In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles and passed through 16 countries, including France, Spain, Italy, Slovenia, and Turkey. They live on a very tight budget, spending less than €3 per day each, and rely on free accommodation, camping, and hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. They eat simple foods like pasta, bread, and seasonal fruits and vegetables, and occasionally dumpster dive for food. Their next destination is Armenia, and they plan to continue into Asia and eventually cycle across the Pacific and the American continent, with no end date in sight.

samples.summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who quit their jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world. They have no set plans or agenda, and they are living on less than three euros a day. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping, couchsurfing, and warmshowers. They have been on the road for 356 days, covering almost 7,000 miles and visiting 16 countries. They started in London and have cycled through Europe, including France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey. They are currently in Armenia and plan to continue cycling through Asia, across the Pacific, and down the length of the American continent.

samples.source:
pablo mandado and ilze zebolde have no plans , no agenda , no cause to fight for and they are certainly in no hurry -- the couple simply has a dream to ` discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time . ' 
and , after quitting their restaurant jobs in manchester , the intrepid cyclists are doing it as cheaply as they possibly can . 
spanish pablo , 27 , and latvian ilze , 31 , who met in riga in 2011 , are off to a flying start as they approach their first year of their open-ended odyssey on the road . 
in 356 days so far they 've covered almost 7,000 miles ( 11,131.92 km by their measurements ) and been through 16 countries . 
ilze zebolde , 31 , takes in her surrounds as she and pablo mandado take a break in their cycle journey around the world
pablo , 27 , and ilze , 31 , stop for a picture in bosnia , one of the 16 countries they 've been through since leaving london last year
latvian ilze sets up camp , the most common means of accommodation for her and pablo , on the stunning lake bled in slovenia
ilze points at the winding road that she and pablo had climb in spain 's sierra nevada with their 130 kg of gear ( including bicycles )
with no plans or agenda , ilze and pablo are happy to stop and take in stunning views , such as this from a roadside in the french alps
in that time they have been astonishingly living on less than three euros each a day , or by their meticulous calculations 10 euro cents per kilometre . 
they keep costs down by relying on free accommodation , along with not needing a budget for transport -- their legs have that covered . 
usually they pitch a tent under the stars and camp ( 161 nights of the 256 ) but also use hosting websites such as couchsurfing ( 66 nights ) and warmshowers ( 44 nights ) . 
sometimes , they get a good night 's sleep courtesy of the kindness of strangers . 
showers are ` sometimes daily , sometimes weekly , ' admits pablo . 
this leaves food as their only major expense , and that takes up just 2.74 euros each per day of their 2.99 total outlay . 
ilze often stars in their images with pablo the designated photographer , but she does n't seem to mind after another hill climb
pablo gives up his camera for a moment , though , as latvian ilze captures her spanish boyfriend taking a rest on the road
while they often pitch their tent in stunning settings , this pedestrian tunnel during their journey through turkey is n't one of them
rolling green hills and a shimmering lake greeted the duo in the alps as their open-ended odyssey continued
when asked on their blog , thecrazytravel , how they can possibly live like this , pablo answered simply . 
` pasta , bread , rice , eggs , milk , seasonal fruits and vegetables . 
often we get invited for a meal , or for some free veggies or fruits , ' he said . 
` we pick up wild fruits occasionally as well , and dumpster diving was an option in western countries where half of the food production end up in the bin . ' 
pablo and ilze started in london before heading south-east and working their way through france , first down the west coast and then the south after a loop through spain and portugal . 
pedal power then took them through the north of italy , slovenia , croatia , bosnia and herzegovina , montenegro , albania , macedonia , greece and into turkey . 
ilze walks with her bike while pablo trails behind to capture a snowy landscape in turkey , which they traversed the entire north of
pablo and ilze 's tent in a field in bosnia - this is their usual means of accommodation although they often use hosting websites
pabo and ilze take a break in an italian mountain town as they work their way from france towards eastern europe
pablo rides along the waterside in thessaloniki , greece , one of more than 225 stops they 've made in their journey so far
all landscapes and settings are greeting pablo and ilze , including moody forests in france as they rode along both coasts
ilze rides into the clouds as pedal power takes her and pablo through eastern europe and towards asia , their next continent
the view from pablo and ilze 's tent as they awake to another day in the saddle as they live out their dream
pablo shows off the huge amount of gear he and ilze need to carry as they work their way around the world
` cycling over the bridge at the border between greece and turkey was symbolic , ' pablo says . 
` riding away from europe , finally crossing into a different continent . 
finally going further away and into the unknown . ' 
they traversed the entire northern coast of turkey , before riding through georgia and their latest destination , armenia , and they plan to ` continue into asia , across the pacific with the idea to cycle all the length of the american continent . ' 
` we are going to be on the road for the following years , ' they say .
samples.summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who have quit their jobs and embarked on a cycling journey around the world. They have no specific plans or agenda, and their goal is to explore different parts of the planet at their own pace. They have been on the road for almost a year and have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live on a budget of less than three euros each per day, mainly spending on food. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping and hosting websites, to keep costs down. Their next destination is Asia, and they plan to continue cycling across the Pacific and through the entire length of the American continent. They anticipate being on the road for several more years.

samples.source:
a three-bedroom apartment in one of the most expensive areas to live in britain has been put on the market for just £ 575,000 - but the ` bargain ' property comes with a catch . 
the knightsbridge flat , london , which is on sale for a fraction of the price of neighbouring homes , has just three years left on the lease . 
the cost would work out at £ 191,000 per year , or £ 15,000 per month - which is around the going rate for renting a three-bedroom flat in the area . 
the entrance to the flats in one of the most expensive areas to live in britain where a three-bedroom apartment has been put on the market for just £ 575,000
but if any buyer decides to extend the lease , the property could be worth upwards of £ 6 million . 
the ` unmodernised ' maisonette in the in exclusive egerton place , is described as ` bright and well proportioned ' property with 1,990 sq/ft of space . 
it boasts three bedrooms , two bathrooms , a reception room and utility room along with a lift , parking and a communal garden . 
the property is being sold by russell simpson for £ 575,000 - the same price as a three-bedroom house in stanmore , middlesex . 
it is one of two maisonettes being sold with three years remaining on the lease . 
both homes will need to be modernised , with the second , larger property - also on egerton place - on the market for £ 595,000 . 
the next cheapest three-bedroom property in knightsbridge costs £ 1.5 million , and this flat is only offered with a 28-year lease . 
but the property comes with a catch , not only is it in dire need of renovation , ( such as in one of its bedrooms , pictured ) the home has just three years left on the lease
the cost for £ 575,000 on a three year lease would work out at £ 191,000 per year , or £ 15,000 per month - which is around the going rate for renting a three-bedroom flat in the area , plus renovation works which are needed , such as in the living room ( pictured )
but if any buyer decides to extend the lease , the ` bright and well proportioned ' property with 1,990 sq/ft of space , could be worth upwards of £ 6 million
jake russell , from russell simpson , said : ` properties like this come up once in a blue moon and i think it is an outstanding opportunity . 
` to get properties like this in egerton place is very exciting and the phone has n't stopped ringing , which is quite unusual considering the time of the year with the election around the corner . 
` we have had interest from locals , developers and end users . 
in modernised condition , we would estimate they would sell for between £ 2,750 and £ 3,000 per sq/ft . ' 
this gives the smaller property a £ 6 million prices tag , while the larger maisonette with 2,500 sq/ft of space could be worth £ 7.5 million . 
the current freeholder is thought to be the welcome trust and any buyer would have to negotiate a lease extension with them and , for a 90-year lease , it is likely to cost between £ 3.35 and £ 4.5 million . 
egerton place was built off michael 's grove by john grover and son to the designs of architect mervyn macartney around 1893 . 
the properties introduced a higher quality of architecture to the egerton gardens area with each home featuring four main storeys with basements and garrets , finished in costly two-inch bricks of red and orange . 
estate agents said it was rare for properties with such short leases to come on the market and the phone ` has n't stopped ringing ' about the egerton place apartment
but alex newall , from hanover private office , had a warning to potential buyers : ` it looks cheap , but there will be a massive premium to pay to extend the lease '
leases of all the homes were granted by the smith 's charity trustees in 1894 , and its first occupant was , sir evan macgregor , permanent secretary to the admiralty . 
other residents of high status included the dowager lady lawrence , probably the widow of the first baron lawrence , at no. 5 , and sir henry fielding dickens , q.c. , son of the novelist charles at no. 2 . 
one property consultant said it was very rare for a pair of properties to come onto the market with such short leases . 
alex newall , from hanover private office , said : ` it looks cheap , but there will be a massive premium to pay to extend the lease . 
` a developer will probably buy it or someone might use it as a rental for three years and then give it back to the freeholder . 
` it is a very quirky situation . 
properties do come up with very short leases like this every so often but it is very rare for somewhere like knightsbridge . 
` i know someone who let their lease run down to eight years and they thought ` right , i need to extend it ' , but by then it was too late and the extension was too much . 
` let it be a warning to check your lease . '

The property, located in Egerton Place, is described as bright and well-proportioned with 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. The cost of £575,000 on a three-year lease would work out at £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, which is around the going rate for renting a three-bedroom flat in the area. If a buyer decides to extend the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The property needs renovation, and the current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust. Any buyer would have to negotiate a lease extension with them, and for a 90-year lease, it is likely to cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. It is rare for properties with such short leases to come

egerton place was built off michael 's grove by john grover and son to the designs of architect mervyn macartney around 1893 . 
the properties introduced a higher quality of architecture to the egerton gardens area with each home featuring four main storeys with basements and garrets , finished in costly two-inch bricks of red and orange . 
estate agents said it was rare for properties with such short leases to come on the market and the phone ` has n't stopped ringing ' about the egerton place apartment

leases of all the homes were granted by the smith 's charity trustees in 1894 , and its first occupant was , sir evan macgregor , permanent secretary to the admiralty . 
other residents of high status included the dowager lady lawrence , probably the widow of the first baron lawrence , at no. 5 , and sir henry fielding dickens , q.c. , son of the novelist charles at no. 2 . 
one property consultant said it was very rare for a pair of properties to come onto the market with such short leases . 
alex newall , from hanover private office , said : ` it looks cheap , but there will be a massive premium to pay to extend the lease . 
` a developer will probably buy it or someone might use it as a rental for three years and then give it back to the freeholder . 
` it is a very quirky situation . 
properties do come up with very short leases like this every so often but it is very rare for somewhere like knightsbridge . 
` i know someone who let their lease run down to eight years and they thought ` right , i need to extend it ' , but by then it was too late and the extension was too much . 
` let it be a warning to check your lease . '
samples.summary: A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London is on the market for £575,000, significantly cheaper than neighboring properties. However, the catch is that the lease only has three years remaining. The cost of the lease would be £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, which is similar to the rental rate in the area. If the buyer decides to extend the lease, the property could be worth over £6 million. The apartment is described as "bright and well proportioned" with 1,990 sq/ft of space and includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. The property needs renovation. Another larger property in the same area is also on the market for £595,000 with three years remaining on the lease. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge costs £1.5 million with a 28-year lease. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and negotiating a lease extension is estimated to cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease.
